comment_text.mn103:2.2: Bhavābhava does not mean “existence and non-existence” but is a distributive compound, “this or that state of existence”. Indian religious texts are full of discussions about different heavens and hells. The Buddha’s goal is liberation, not rebirth in heaven.
comment_text.mn103:3.2: These are the sets of practices later called the 37 bodhiyapakkhiyā dhammā, the “wings to awakening”. Here they are presented as an essential summary of the Buddha’s teachings. They form the backbone of the final book of the Saṁyuttanikāya, the Maggavagga (or Mahāvagga). It is likely that the Buddha was referring to the earliest recension of this text. They are found as a summary of the Buddha’s teachings at DN 16:3.50.5, DN 29:17.3, MN 104:5.3, and AN 8.19:17.2 = Ud 5.5:25.2.
comment_text.mn103:5.2: “Meaning” is attha, the “purpose”, “goal”, or “benefit” of the teaching. “Phrasing is byañjana (also spelled vyañjana), the “letter”, “syllable”, or “expression”, with the root sense of “differentiating”. Such passages show that concern for both aspects were present from the earliest times. | “Most amenable” is suvacatara, literally, “more easy to speak to”.
comment_text.mn103:5.12: When the source of the problem has been identified, it should be remembered so that it does not recur.
comment_text.mn103:6.2: At AN 6.61:10.5 we see a group of monks discussing a verse of the Dhamma, with different interpretations, and the Buddha praises them as having all spoken well. Thus it is not that any different interpretation is wrong, but that some different interpretations conflict with the fundamental purpose of the teaching, the attha.
comment_text.mn103:7.6: One of the reasons why the phrasing is considered less important is that the Buddhist texts are constructed with a massive amount of redundancy. In any question of significance, a variation in a phrase or a word in one place is almost always clarified with reference to another passage.
comment_text.mn103:9.1: Namely, a  transgression against the Monastic Code, the Vinaya. Such offences are a collective ethical standard that require other monastics to resolve, at least by hearing a confession.
comment_text.mn103:10.1: Vinaya is not meant to be applied legalistically or cruelly, but to uplift and reform. | Punctuation in Mahāsaṅgīti is incorrect. The following iti belongs on this line, as shown in the repetition below.
comment_text.mn103:10.3: If the problem can be resolved without resorting to legal proceedings, it should.
comment_text.mn103:14.3: Wisdom knows that sometimes there is nothing to be done. That doesn’t mean one gives up, but rather, that sometimes patience is the best way. Note that this is the last option, however, and gentle intervention is always preferred.
comment_text.mn103:15.1: Readings include vacīsaṁsāro, vacīsaṁhāro, and vacīsaṅkhāro. Vacīsaṁsāro is found, without recorded variants, in the parallel passage at AN 2.63:1.1. The commentary here glosses with vacanasañcāro, while the subcommentary to AN 2.63 has pavattamānā, both of which support the dominant reading vacīsaṁsāro. Their explanations differ, however as the commentary here explains as spreading rumors from one place to another, while at AN 2.63 it is said to be ongoing arguing. Since the normal meaning of saṁsāra is “endless ongoing”, and since, in both MN and AN, this follows a passage where disputes were supposed to have been settled, perhaps the sense is “continuing to bring up matters that have been settled”.

translation_text.mn103:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kusinārā, in the Forest of Offerings.
translation_text.mn103:1.3: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
translation_text.mn103:2.1: “Mendicants, is this what you think of me?
translation_text.mn103:2.2: ‘The ascetic Gotama teaches the Dhamma for the sake of robes, almsfood, lodgings, or rebirth in this or that state.’”
translation_text.mn103:2.3: “No sir, we don’t think of you that way.”

translation_text.mn103:2.8: what then do you think of me?”
translation_text.mn103:2.10: ‘The Buddha is sympathetic and wants what’s best for us.

translation_text.mn103:3.1: In that case, each and every one of you should train in the things I have taught from my direct knowledge, that is:

translation_text.mn103:12.2: ‘I will be troubled but the other individual won’t be hurt, for they’re not irritable and acrimonious. However, they hold fast to their views, refusing to let go. Nevertheless, I can draw them away from the unskillful and establish them in the skillful.
translation_text.mn103:12.3: But for me to be troubled is a minor matter.
translation_text.mn103:12.5: that I can draw them away from the unskillful and establish them in the skillful.’
translation_text.mn103:12.6: If that’s what you think, then it’s appropriate to speak to them.
translation_text.mn103:13.2: ‘I will be troubled and the other individual will be hurt, for they’re irritable and acrimonious. And they hold fast to their views, refusing to let go. Nevertheless, I can draw them away from the unskillful and establish them in the skillful.
translation_text.mn103:13.3: But for me to be troubled and the other individual to get hurt is a minor matter.
translation_text.mn103:13.5: that I can draw them away from the unskillful and establish them in the skillful.’
translation_text.mn103:13.6: If that’s what you think, then it’s appropriate to speak to them.
translation_text.mn103:14.2: ‘I will be troubled and the other individual will be hurt, for they’re irritable and acrimonious. And they hold fast to their views, refusing to let go. I cannot draw them away from the unskillful and establish them in the skillful.’
translation_text.mn103:14.3: Don’t underestimate the value of equanimity regarding such an individual.
translation_text.mn103:15.1: As you train in harmony, appreciating each other, without quarreling, the sides might continue to bring up settled issues with each other, with contempt for each other’s views, resentful, bitter, and exasperated.
translation_text.mn103:15.2: In this case you should approach whichever mendicant you think is most amenable among those who side with one party and say to them:
translation_text.mn103:15.3: ‘Reverend, as we were training, the sides continued to bring up settled issues with each other. If the Ascetic knew about this, would he criticize it?’
translation_text.mn103:15.4: Answering rightly, the mendicant should say:
translation_text.mn103:15.6: ‘But without giving that up, reverend, can one realize extinguishment?’
translation_text.mn103:15.7: Answering rightly, the mendicant should say:
translation_text.mn103:16.1: Then they should approach whichever mendicant they think is most amenable among those who side with the other party and say to them:
translation_text.mn103:16.2: ‘Reverend, as we were training, the sides continued to bring up settled issues with each other. If the Ascetic knew about this, would he criticize it?’
translation_text.mn103:16.3: Answering rightly, the mendicant should say:
translation_text.mn103:16.5: ‘But without giving that up, reverend, can one realize extinguishment?’
translation_text.mn103:16.6: Answering rightly, the mendicant should say:
translation_text.mn103:17.1: If others should ask that mendicant:
translation_text.mn103:17.2: ‘Were you the venerable who drew those mendicants away from the unskillful and established them in the skillful?’
translation_text.mn103:17.3: Answering rightly, the mendicant should say:
translation_text.mn103:17.4: ‘Well, reverends, I approached the Buddha. He taught me the Dhamma. After hearing that teaching I explained it to those mendicants.
translation_text.mn103:17.5: When those mendicants heard that teaching they were drawn away from the unskillful and established in the skillful.’
translation_text.mn103:17.6: Answering in this way, that mendicant doesn’t glorify themselves or put others down. They answer in line with the teaching, with no legitimate grounds for rebuttal and criticism.”
translation_text.mn103:17.7: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn103:17.8: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
